I am not sure whether your requirement is to provide dynamic inputs
without=
 changing/recompiling your test code.  If yes, you may want to
try Jetif wh=
ich takes declarative parameters from an XML like this...

<method name=3D"=
testSomething">
    <param>42.0</param>
    <param handler=3D"array">value1=
, value2, value3</param>
    <param>32</param>
    <expected>true</expected=
>
</method>

It can also return values for each test run.  You can also men=
tioned
the data types for the data you pass.

~JAK

On 4/18/05, Ilja Preuss=
 <preuss@...> wrote:
>  junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
>  > Hii .. I m  =
just starting off in JUnit and wanted to know if there is
>  > any way I ca=
n test methods which take input from console input instead
>  > of me suppl=
ying the inputs in JUNIT??.. i dont know if the question is
>  > well frome=
d ..I hope u get the gist.... Thanx in advance
>  
>  Remember that System.=
in is a simple InputStream. So, if you'd refactor the
>  method you want to=
 test to work on an arbitrary stream instead of just
>  System.in, your tes=
ts could use some kind of in-memory stream
>  (ByteArrayInputStream, for ex=
ample).
>  
>  Cheers, Ilja
>
